Channing E. Sweitzer, president of
the New York-New Jersey Alumni
Association, in introducing Dr. Bowman, called for the formation of an
alumni club to insure cooperation
with the University. "For years," he
said, "the Hopkins alumni have met
only at irregular intervals, sometimes
only once a year . . . Through this organization we of the New York-New
Jersey Alumni Club hope to be of
some assistance to Doctor Bowman
at Homewood."
Dr. Bowman, throughout his speech,
stressed the need for a healthy distrust of "rugged common sense as a
sovereign remedy."
"No miracles are performed anywhere today," he said, "except in that
city on the Potomac, ironically named
after an engineer accustomed to
measuring things exactly and accurately.

Richard B. Whitten
Urges Peace Plan
For Student Group
Speaks At Levering To N. S.
L. And American League
Against War And Fascism
Declaring that there must be ternal vigilance by students in the
struggle for peace, Richard Babb
Whitten, director of Commonwealth
College in Arkansas, Friday urged
the Permanent Student Peace Council, authorized by student vote at
Thursday's assembly, to take the
lead in the student fight against
war.
Mr. Whitten was the main speaker at a meeting sponsored jointly by
the American League Against War
and Fascism and the National Student League as a part of the National Student Mobilization for Peace.
Reverend John Hutchinson, assistant pastor of Brown Memorial
Church, attacked the present economic order as one which inevitably
produces world wars as an expression of the international struggle for
markets and profits. As a representative of the Youth Commission of
the American League Against War
and Fascism, he urged students to
organize in the common struggle for
peace through the medium of the
League.
Mr. Whitten asserted that "thinking students not only in this country, but in the whole world are concerning themselves with the great
problem before them—war! Even for
those who are without any social
philosophy and expect to blast out a
little niche for themselves, war destroys all hopes and opportunities."
Continuing, the speaker declared
that it is therefore intelligent for
students to ask: Why participate in
war at all? Instead of fighting in
war, he urged students to organize
for peace and for the abolition of
the causes of war.

Dorm Ping-Pong Match
Reaches Semi-Final Play
The Dorm ping-pong match is rapidly reaching the semi-final stage.
the few remaining matches promise
to hold great excitement in store.
The most exciting match to be played
is that between Dr. John A. Curtis,
instructor in mathematics, and Vincent Giacinti.
Dr. Curtis made a name for himself all during his college career as a
tennis player. He was number one
tennis singles player at Northwestern, and ranks ninth on the Western
Lawn Tennis Association's ranking
list. During the last two years, he has
been singles champion at Harvard,
and winner of various New England
tennis tournaments.
Vincent Giacinti, his opponent,
made a name for himself in the pingpong match last year as a leader in
the semi-finals. Bob Kramer, who has
advanced to the quarter-finals, and
Iry Milberg, who has also reached
the semi-final stage, promise to provide threats toward the championship.

Lieutenant. Commander Philip Van
Horn VVIeems, U. S. N. (Retired) recently appointed professor of aerial
navigation in the Johns Hopkins Evening School, will be the main speaker
at the student assembly to be held
Thursday, November 14, 1935.
The assembly will be sponsored by
the Tau Beta Pi fraternity, and will
be devoted to the initiation of members into this honorary undergraduate engineering fraternity.
Is Noted Author
The courses of such great flyers
as Byrd, Post, Ellsworth, and Lindbergh have been plotted by Commander Weems. In addition to his
nautical ability, Commander Weems
is also the author of Air Navigation,
Line of Position Book, and Star Altitude Curves. The first of these
Air Navigation, was awarded a gold
medal in 1931 by the Aero Club of
France.
Mr. Weems struck up a lasting
friendship with Dr. Isaiah Bowman,
meeting him in connection with his
work in geology.
Invented Stop-Watch
As an inventor, Commander Weems
is responsible for the second-setting
stop-watch, which was carried by
Post and Gatty on their flight around
the world.
Weems graduated from the United
States Naval Academy in 1912. He
played football, basketball, and was
a member of the boxing and wrestling teams, as well as the crew. From
1924 to 1927, he taught navigation
at the Naval Academy, and in 1931
and 1932 was research officer
air navigation for the Navy Department.
Commander VVieems will talk on
aviation in general, with references
to particular flights.

"No one can formulate a single
sweeping remedy for the troubles
that beset private educational institutions today. The genius of hard
work is the first requirement of all
of us who expect to share in the further building of the Johns Hopkins
University."
Thus spoke Dr. Isaiah Bowman,
fifth President of the Hopkins, in his
keynote address delivered last Friday at a dinner of the alumni of New
York and New Jersey at the Fraternity Club Building, Madison Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, New
York. More than 175 persons, including David H. Levy and Clarence
Weimer of the Beta Circle of Omicron Delta Kappa, attended the dinner.

"There was a time whorl a certain
rugged common sense, as we called
it, was a sovereign remedy. In all
ages it has had its limitations. Common sense told men that the world
was flat, that locomotives could not
pull more than their own weight uphill. that disease was spread by
the air. How do we know that common sense applied to many of our
present-day troubles is not as ludicrous? College should attempt to
instill common sense, but it must also
teach things beyond common sense.
"A university should let no student
be without a profound appreciation
of the truth that the greatest single
fact about humanity is its willingness
to advance across the border of experience.

Tuesday, November 12, 1935

The Nazi Olympics
In his Pi D. E. address last Thursday, Arthur Garfield Hays dwelled for a while on the question of the
'36 Olympics, attacking it—as he does most things—
from the point of view of a restraint on civil liberties.
Perhaps without quite knowing it, he struck very close
to home by raising this issue here.
The Johns Hopkins University has sent more men
to the Olympic games than any other single organization. Consequently, we are vitflly interested in whether
or not the United States should take part in any
Olympics held in a country whose every action is so
antithetical to those principles of equality of opportunity that we American holds so dear, and to the high
ideals of sportsmanship for which the Olympics stand.
One of the leaders of the fight to take the Olympics
from Germany is Jeremiah T. Mahoney, president of
the A. A. U., who repeats again and again that "Germany is governed by discriminations" in spite of the
promises that Mr. Hitler made, evidently with his
tongue in his cheek, to give all an equal opportunity to
make the German Olympic team. It is just as ridiculous to believe that Berlin was sincere in pledging
sportsmanship as it is to swallow the Nazis' positive
assertion that President Roosevelt is Jewish and that
his real name is Rosenfeld.

fifty cents to one dollar at night. All
seats at the matinees are fifty cents.

preting its problems in graphic form
to the mass mind. Vassos deplores the
fact that artists are not able to fit
into the present scheme Of things and
roundly condemns those who make
personal adjustments by wandering
into such "experimental and disassociated expressions" and cubism and
surrealism. Holding that art is necessary in bringing order and clarity
to that confused mass of outworn
tradition, accumulated cruelties, irrationalism, and creeds of false prophets which make up our presentday systems, Vassos praises the work
of Rivera, Thomas Benton and
Boardman Robinson as pointing the
way to a useful conception of art.
Artists must, he holds, participate in
the scene in which they live.
And so John Vassos surveys contemporary life, and the result is a
medley of emotional reactions to "the
dead ends and blind alleys from
which there seems to be no escape."
His reactions are those of the average intelligent man. Why is it, he
wonders, that starvation exists in the
midst of plenty? He pictures it by
showing a breadline patiently waiting against the wall of a building in
which are stored bags of grain. But
this is a paradox which has worried
some people centuries before John
Vassos developed a social conscience.
In another case he pictures a philanthropist building bird baths, singing
towers, stone drinking fountains for
horses, and libraries in tenement district, while Cossacks, dressed in
their traditional blue uniforms, drive
starving people away from his door.
He wonders at the justice in the fact
that in many professions able and
eager men are turned away simply
because they are black. The press, the
machine, churches, imperialism, the
rule of the old, justice, and individualists are subjected to the same
emotional questioning.

KEITH'S
Last Thursday night Keith's Theatre opened with May Robson in Three
Kids and a Queen. In the picture
Miss Robson portrays the role of an
extremely wealthy woman, who is
injured, and cared for by a barber.
The newspapers play up the story
that she has been kidnapped, and as
a result she insists the barber keep
her hidden. She is terrified by the
fear that if found she will be committed to an asylum. Finally Miss
Robson is actually kidnapped, and
the barber comes to her aid.

BLUE

By BERNARD PINCK

Salisbury State Teachers Suffer Initial Defeat; Close
Game Throughout

Jays Win First Tilt
McKinney Tallies Deciding
Goal; Captain Randall,
Bernheim, Clisham Star
Saturday afternoon the Jay booters retained the fine reputation which
they own as a good, clean soccer
playing organization. In defeating
the array from Salisbury State Teachers' College, which previous to this
encounter had defeated our boys by
a 4-1 score, the Dotterweich Demons
ably demonstrated their superiority.
The Hopkins horde triumphed, 1-0.
The score, though an indication of
the final result, in no way typifies
the spirit and ability displayed by
the victors. Held scoreless until the
final two minutes of the last quarter, they finally broke through to
put a well-placed shot by the Teachers' net tender.
First Half Tight
The game see-sawed throughout
the first half, with neither team
showing any distinct superiority. No
doubt the ,Blue and Black aggregation could have used the assistance
of their star halfback, Billy McClean,
who was not present. However, with
the return of the booters for the
second half of the fray, the soccerites representing Hopkins led off
with a determined attack. Repelled
by some fine defensive work on the
part of Long and Gibbons of Salisbury, the Blue attack finally broke
through in the form of McKinney,
who scored what proved to be the
winning shot. The score resulted
from a scrimmage in the front of
the goal with McKinney, who was
hurt earlier in the encounter, finally
kicking the ball outside the reach
of the goalie with a low corner shot.
Throughout, the game was marked
by the outstanding playing of such
Jays as Hartke, Clisham, Bernheim,
and Captain Randall. By his excellent showing in the affair on Saturday, Randall bids fair to become a
member of that mythical organization, the All-State Soccer Team.
Coach Dotterweich showed excellent ability as a mentor in the manner in which he conducted the affair
from the sidelines. Substitutes were
used to very good advantage when
the varsity first string men tired,
and Dotterweich's presence itself
loaned an air of assurance during the
course of the contest.
The soccer team can again be seen
in action today when they play the
State Normal team at Towson.

The season has roiled around again
when the physiological processes of
Hopkins men are strangely provoked
and they are impelled by some mysterious urge to build fires in defiance
of police regulations and to march
down Charles Street clamoring for
the football annihilation of St. John's.
This annual outburst of distate for
any part of St. John's—particularly
its gridiron representatives — seems
to be an inherent feature of college
life at the Homewood institution.
From the moment they cross the
threshold of the University, freshmen must develop a keen antagonism for our Annapolis rivals; they
are made to feel that a victory over
St. John's is the ultimum of football
desires.
The pre-game festivities seem to
be as classic as the contest itself.
Stories are told of the thrilling escapades of bygone years. Most of
us, however, remember the feverish
excitement which reigned on the canipus last year, when a freshman enroute to a mail box, was ruthlessly
kidnaped by a group of the Johnnies and brought to the Annapolis
haven. Although the treatment accorded him was not at all that befitting an enemy—a dance was run
in his honor—the affront to the Hopkins pride was tremendous. Studies
were abondoned and organized parties, armed with acetyl chloride, bromine and wooden cudgels, made their
way to the banks of the Severn.
Their efforts were useless, however,
and the unfortunate victim was not
retrieved until the day of the game.

Characterizing the spirit shown in
the other intramural touch football
league games this fall, Teams "A"
and "B", representing the freshman
engineers, repeated their feat of a
short while back when they again
battled to a scoreless tie on Friday
afternoon. "Back to the wall playing" distinguished the type of action
taken by the opposing arrays. Among
the pigskin-minded athletes were
Beeler, Frank, Reynolds, Ham, Chesley, and, Chapman.
A bit more fortunate than the deadlocked engineers were the fighting
0. K. 0.'s who managed to slip one
by the Betas, defeating them, 6-0.
There was no let-up throughout the
contest, the boys battling for their
respective fraternities until the closing minutes found the ball partially
obscured by darkness. A feature of
the game for which the boys deserve
especial commendation was the clean
manner in which the affair was conducted, although the rough and tumble element was naturally present.

Increased Turnout
For Fall Lacrosse
An especially large turnout characterized the fall lacrosse practice
sessions held last week under the
combined guidance of Coaches Kelso
Morrill and Ronald Levy. The men,
representing last year's varsity, junior varsity, and the freshman aggregation of 1935, bolstered by a group
of hopeful freshmen, are progressing
rapidly. Through continued and repeated assaults on the wall on the
upper field and the box lacrosse
goals on the lower field, the shots
of the potential stickmen are vastly
improved.
Coach Morrill ran the squad
through games and exercises designed mainly to provide the candidates with the stamina and wind
needed for the campaign in the
spring. Those members of last year's
varsity squad engaging in these tuning-up activities are Don Naylor,
Dorsey Yearley, Dick Love, Bucky
White, Bob Levi, and Pete Bernheim,
while Katz, Mewshaw, Gusach, Erlanger, and Mitchell were the bulwark from the freshman squad.

PHILIP VAN HORN WEEMS

Richard B. Whitten
Urges Peace Plan
For Student Group
Speaks At Levering To N. S.
L. And American League
Against War And Fascism
Declaring that there must be ternal vigilance by students in the
struggle for peace, Richard Babb
Whitten, director of Commonwealth
College in Arkansas, Friday urged
the Permanent Student Peace Council, authorized by student vote at
Thursday's assembly, to take the
lead in the student fight against
war.
Mr. Whitten was the main speaker at a meeting sponsored jointly by
the American League Against War
and Fascism and the National Student League as a part of the National Student Mobilization for Peace.
Reverend John Hutchinson, assistant pastor of Brown Memorial
Church, attacked the present economic order as one which inevitably
produces world wars as an expression of the international struggle for
markets and profits. As a representative of the Youth Commission of
the American League Against War
and Fascism, he urged students to
organize in the common struggle for
peace through the medium of the
League.
Mr. Whitten asserted that "thinking students not only in this country, but in the whole world are concerning themselves with the great
problem before them—war! Even for
those who are without any social
philosophy and expect to blast out a
little niche for themselves, war destroys all hopes and opportunities."
Continuing, the speaker declared
that it is therefore intelligent for
students to ask: Why participate in
war at all? Instead of fighting in
war, he urged students to organize
for peace and for the abolition of
the causes of war.

Dorm Ping-Pong Match
Reaches Semi-Final Play
The Dorm ping-pong match is rapidly reaching the semi-final stage.
the few remaining matches promise
to hold great excitement in store.
The most exciting match to be played
is that between Dr. John A. Curtis,
instructor in mathematics, and Vincent Giacinti.
Dr. Curtis made a name for himself all during his college career as a
tennis player. He was number one
tennis singles player at Northwestern, and ranks ninth on the Western
Lawn Tennis Association's ranking
list. During the last two years, he has
been singles champion at Harvard,
and winner of various New England
tennis tournaments.
Vincent Giacinti, his opponent,
made a name for himself in the pingpong match last year as a leader in
the semi-finals. Bob Kramer, who has
advanced to the quarter-finals, and
Iry Milberg, who has also reached
the semi-final stage, promise to provide threats toward the championship.

Lieutenant. Commander Philip Van
Horn VVIeems, U. S. N. (Retired) recently appointed professor of aerial
navigation in the Johns Hopkins Evening School, will be the main speaker
at the student assembly to be held
Thursday, November 14, 1935.
The assembly will be sponsored by
the Tau Beta Pi fraternity, and will
be devoted to the initiation of members into this honorary undergraduate engineering fraternity.
Is Noted Author
The courses of such great flyers
as Byrd, Post, Ellsworth, and Lindbergh have been plotted by Commander Weems. In addition to his
nautical ability, Commander Weems
is also the author of Air Navigation,
Line of Position Book, and Star Altitude Curves. The first of these
Air Navigation, was awarded a gold
medal in 1931 by the Aero Club of
France.
Mr. Weems struck up a lasting
friendship with Dr. Isaiah Bowman,
meeting him in connection with his
work in geology.
Invented Stop-Watch
As an inventor, Commander Weems
is responsible for the second-setting
stop-watch, which was carried by
Post and Gatty on their flight around
the world.
Weems graduated from the United
States Naval Academy in 1912. He
played football, basketball, and was
a member of the boxing and wrestling teams, as well as the crew. From
1924 to 1927, he taught navigation
at the Naval Academy, and in 1931
and 1932 was research officer
air navigation for the Navy Department.
Commander VVieems will talk on
aviation in general, with references
to particular flights.

"There was a time whorl a certain
rugged common sense, as we called
it, was a sovereign remedy. In all
ages it has had its limitations. Common sense told men that the world
was flat, that locomotives could not
pull more than their own weight uphill. that disease was spread by
the air. How do we know that common sense applied to many of our
present-day troubles is not as ludicrous? College should attempt to
instill common sense, but it must also
teach things beyond common sense.
"A university should let no student
be without a profound appreciation
of the truth that the greatest single
fact about humanity is its willingness
to advance across the border of experience.

Tuesday, November 12, 1935

The Nazi Olympics
In his Pi D. E. address last Thursday, Arthur Garfield Hays dwelled for a while on the question of the
'36 Olympics, attacking it—as he does most things—
from the point of view of a restraint on civil liberties.
Perhaps without quite knowing it, he struck very close
to home by raising this issue here.
The Johns Hopkins University has sent more men
to the Olympic games than any other single organization. Consequently, we are vitflly interested in whether
or not the United States should take part in any
Olympics held in a country whose every action is so
antithetical to those principles of equality of opportunity that we American holds so dear, and to the high
ideals of sportsmanship for which the Olympics stand.
One of the leaders of the fight to take the Olympics
from Germany is Jeremiah T. Mahoney, president of
the A. A. U., who repeats again and again that "Germany is governed by discriminations" in spite of the
promises that Mr. Hitler made, evidently with his
tongue in his cheek, to give all an equal opportunity to
make the German Olympic team. It is just as ridiculous to believe that Berlin was sincere in pledging
sportsmanship as it is to swallow the Nazis' positive
assertion that President Roosevelt is Jewish and that
his real name is Rosenfeld.

preting its problems in graphic form
to the mass mind. Vassos deplores the
fact that artists are not able to fit
into the present scheme Of things and
roundly condemns those who make
personal adjustments by wandering
into such "experimental and disassociated expressions" and cubism and
surrealism. Holding that art is necessary in bringing order and clarity
to that confused mass of outworn
tradition, accumulated cruelties, irrationalism, and creeds of false prophets which make up our presentday systems, Vassos praises the work
of Rivera, Thomas Benton and
Boardman Robinson as pointing the
way to a useful conception of art.
Artists must, he holds, participate in
the scene in which they live.
And so John Vassos surveys contemporary life, and the result is a
medley of emotional reactions to "the
dead ends and blind alleys from
which there seems to be no escape."
His reactions are those of the average intelligent man. Why is it, he
wonders, that starvation exists in the
midst of plenty? He pictures it by
showing a breadline patiently waiting against the wall of a building in
which are stored bags of grain. But
this is a paradox which has worried
some people centuries before John
Vassos developed a social conscience.
In another case he pictures a philanthropist building bird baths, singing
towers, stone drinking fountains for
horses, and libraries in tenement district, while Cossacks, dressed in
their traditional blue uniforms, drive
starving people away from his door.
He wonders at the justice in the fact
that in many professions able and
eager men are turned away simply
because they are black. The press, the
machine, churches, imperialism, the
rule of the old, justice, and individualists are subjected to the same
emotional questioning.

KEITH'S
Last Thursday night Keith's Theatre opened with May Robson in Three
Kids and a Queen. In the picture
Miss Robson portrays the role of an
extremely wealthy woman, who is
injured, and cared for by a barber.
The newspapers play up the story
that she has been kidnapped, and as
a result she insists the barber keep
her hidden. She is terrified by the
fear that if found she will be committed to an asylum. Finally Miss
Robson is actually kidnapped, and
the barber comes to her aid.

BLUE

By BERNARD PINCK

Salisbury State Teachers Suffer Initial Defeat; Close
Game Throughout

Jays Win First Tilt
McKinney Tallies Deciding
Goal; Captain Randall,
Bernheim, Clisham Star
Saturday afternoon the Jay booters retained the fine reputation which
they own as a good, clean soccer
playing organization. In defeating
the array from Salisbury State Teachers' College, which previous to this
encounter had defeated our boys by
a 4-1 score, the Dotterweich Demons
ably demonstrated their superiority.
The Hopkins horde triumphed, 1-0.
The score, though an indication of
the final result, in no way typifies
the spirit and ability displayed by
the victors. Held scoreless until the
final two minutes of the last quarter, they finally broke through to
put a well-placed shot by the Teachers' net tender.
First Half Tight
The game see-sawed throughout
the first half, with neither team
showing any distinct superiority. No
doubt the ,Blue and Black aggregation could have used the assistance
of their star halfback, Billy McClean,
who was not present. However, with
the return of the booters for the
second half of the fray, the soccerites representing Hopkins led off
with a determined attack. Repelled
by some fine defensive work on the
part of Long and Gibbons of Salisbury, the Blue attack finally broke
through in the form of McKinney,
who scored what proved to be the
winning shot. The score resulted
from a scrimmage in the front of
the goal with McKinney, who was
hurt earlier in the encounter, finally
kicking the ball outside the reach
of the goalie with a low corner shot.
Throughout, the game was marked
by the outstanding playing of such
Jays as Hartke, Clisham, Bernheim,
and Captain Randall. By his excellent showing in the affair on Saturday, Randall bids fair to become a
member of that mythical organization, the All-State Soccer Team.
Coach Dotterweich showed excellent ability as a mentor in the manner in which he conducted the affair
from the sidelines. Substitutes were
used to very good advantage when
the varsity first string men tired,
and Dotterweich's presence itself
loaned an air of assurance during the
course of the contest.
The soccer team can again be seen
in action today when they play the
State Normal team at Towson.

The season has roiled around again
when the physiological processes of
Hopkins men are strangely provoked
and they are impelled by some mysterious urge to build fires in defiance
of police regulations and to march
down Charles Street clamoring for
the football annihilation of St. John's.
This annual outburst of distate for
any part of St. John's—particularly
its gridiron representatives — seems
to be an inherent feature of college
life at the Homewood institution.
From the moment they cross the
threshold of the University, freshmen must develop a keen antagonism for our Annapolis rivals; they
are made to feel that a victory over
St. John's is the ultimum of football
desires.
The pre-game festivities seem to
be as classic as the contest itself.
Stories are told of the thrilling escapades of bygone years. Most of
us, however, remember the feverish
excitement which reigned on the canipus last year, when a freshman enroute to a mail box, was ruthlessly
kidnaped by a group of the Johnnies and brought to the Annapolis
haven. Although the treatment accorded him was not at all that befitting an enemy—a dance was run
in his honor—the affront to the Hopkins pride was tremendous. Studies
were abondoned and organized parties, armed with acetyl chloride, bromine and wooden cudgels, made their
way to the banks of the Severn.
Their efforts were useless, however,
and the unfortunate victim was not
retrieved until the day of the game.

Characterizing the spirit shown in
the other intramural touch football
league games this fall, Teams "A"
and "B", representing the freshman
engineers, repeated their feat of a
short while back when they again
battled to a scoreless tie on Friday
afternoon. "Back to the wall playing" distinguished the type of action
taken by the opposing arrays. Among
the pigskin-minded athletes were
Beeler, Frank, Reynolds, Ham, Chesley, and, Chapman.
A bit more fortunate than the deadlocked engineers were the fighting
0. K. 0.'s who managed to slip one
by the Betas, defeating them, 6-0.
There was no let-up throughout the
contest, the boys battling for their
respective fraternities until the closing minutes found the ball partially
obscured by darkness. A feature of
the game for which the boys deserve
especial commendation was the clean
manner in which the affair was conducted, although the rough and tumble element was naturally present.

J. H. FURST CO.

Increased Turnout
For Fall Lacrosse
An especially large turnout characterized the fall lacrosse practice
sessions held last week under the
combined guidance of Coaches Kelso
Morrill and Ronald Levy. The men,
representing last year's varsity, junior varsity, and the freshman aggregation of 1935, bolstered by a group
of hopeful freshmen, are progressing
rapidly. Through continued and repeated assaults on the wall on the
upper field and the box lacrosse
goals on the lower field, the shots
of the potential stickmen are vastly
improved.
Coach Morrill ran the squad
through games and exercises designed mainly to provide the candidates with the stamina and wind
needed for the campaign in the
spring. Those members of last year's
varsity squad engaging in these tuning-up activities are Don Naylor,
Dorsey Yearley, Dick Love, Bucky
White, Bob Levi, and Pete Bernheim,
while Katz, Mewshaw, Gusach, Erlanger, and Mitchell were the bulwark from the freshman squad.
